chunk_text: biotechnology is the use of micro-organisms to make things that people want, often involving industrial production.
microbiology is the study of micro-organisms and their effect on humans.
bacteria are unicellular micro-organisms.
viruses are sub-microscopic infectious agents that are unable to grow or reproduce outside a host cell.
fungi are simple organisms, often microscopic, that cannot photosynthesise and feed as parasites or saprophytes.
protoctista are unicellular organisms.
anaerobically means without oxygen.
fermentation is anaerobic respiration in yeast that produces ethanol.
lactic acid is the product of anaerobic respiration in animal cells.

genetic engineering/genetic modification is the process of inserting new genetic information into existing cells in order to modify a specific organism for the purpose of changing its characteristics.
mycoprotein is fungal protein.
biogas generator/digester takes in waste material or plants, and biogas and useful fertilisers come out the other end.
exothermic reaction is that which produces heat energy.
carbohydrase is enzyme which breaks down carbohydrates.
distillation is process of purifying a liquid by boiling it and condensing its vapours.
carbon-neutral process is whereby the amount of carbon emitted is matched by the amount absorbed.
red blood cell is type of blood cell that carries oxygen around the body.
chromosome is a strand of DNA carrying genetic information.
DNA is nucleic acid containing the genetic instructions used in the development and functioning of all known living organisms and some viruses.
homologous chromosomes are a pair of chromosomes having the same gene sequences, each derived from one parent.
karyotype is map of the chromosomes in the nucleus of a single cell.
autosomes are chromosomes that are not sex chromosomes.
double helix is pair of parallel helices intertwined about a common axis.
adenine is one of the four bases that comprise DNA which pairs with thymine.
thymine is one of the four bases that comprise DNA which pairs with adenine.
guanine is one of the four bases that comprise DNA which pairs with cytosine.
cytosine is one of the four bases that comprise DNA which pairs with guanine.
nucleotide is a building block of DNA or RNA which consists of a sugar, a phosphate, and one of the four bases.
polynucleotide is long chains of linked nucleotides.
somatic cells are any of the cells of a plant or animal except the reproductive cells.
mitosis is cell division in which the nucleus divides into nuclei containing the same number of identical chromosomes.
chromatids are the two strands of a chromosome that separate during mitosis.
daughter cells are the two identical cells that are formed when a cell reproduces itself by splitting into two.
stem cells are cells that have the ability to grow into other kinds of cells.
differentiated means made different.
ovary is the female sex organ that produces ova.
testes are the male sex organ that produces sperm.
ova are egg cells (reproductive cells) produced by the ovary.
sperm are male reproductive cells produced by the testes.
meiosis is the type of cell division that creates egg and sperm cells.
dominant is an allele where the characteristic is expressed in the phenotype even if only one copy of the allele is present.
recessive is an allele where the characteristic is only expressed in the phenotype if two copies of the allele are present.
alleles are different forms of the same gene.
monohybrid is hybrid between two parents that have a difference of only one gene.
homozygous means having two identical alleles for a particular feature.
heterozygous means having two different alleles for a particular feature.
genotypes are a description of the alleles of an individual for a given genetic trait.
phenotype is a description of the physical appearance of an individual relating to a given genetic trait.
albinism is a genetic condition in which no melanin pigment is formed in the cells.
spinal cord is a column of neurons within the backbone.
neurons are nerve cells.
sensory receptors are nerve endings that can sense stimuli, e.g. pressure, pain, temperature, and start a nerve impulse that sends this information back to the brain.
affector (afferent) neuron is that sends impulses from organs to the spinal cord and brain.
effector (efferent) neuron is that sends impulses from the brain and spinal cord to organs.
dendrites are tree-like branches from nerve cell bodies that receive signals from other nerve cells at synapses.
axon is a long process from nerve cell that carries the nerve impulse.
myelin sheath is a fatty insulating sheath that grows around many nerves.
action potential is a short-term change in the electrical potential on the surface of a cell when it is stimulated.
synapse is the junction between two neurons (axon-to-dendrite) or between a neuron and a muscle.
neurotransmitters are chemicals that transmit nerve impulses across synapses.
neuromuscular junctions are the junction between an axon terminal of a motor neuron and a muscle fibre.
cranium is the part of the skull that encloses the brain.
cranial nerves are 12 pairs of nerves that emerge directly from the brain stem.
spinal nerves are mixed nerves containing both sensory and motor neurons.
grey matter is areas in the brain and spinal cord that consist of unmyelinated nerve cells.
fore brain is the large frontal area of the human brain.
relay neurons are neurons which are activated by other neurons.
mental illness is a general term referring to psychological, emotional, or behavioural disorders.
reflexes are automatic, instinctive, unlearned reactions to stimuli.
reflex arc is the neural path of a reflex.
reflex action is an automatic, instinctive, unlearned reaction to a stimulus.
dorsal root is the root at the back of the spinal cord.
ventral root is the root at the front of the spinal cord.
addicted means compulsively or physiologically dependent on something habit-forming.
withdrawal symptoms are a set of unpleasant effects upon the body caused by a sudden stopping of using a drug.
alcoholics are people who are addicted to alcohol.
topic: How does alcohol affect your body?

chunk_text: cirrhosis of the liver is endstage liver disease.
topic: How does alcohol affect your body?

chunk_text: binge drinking means consuming excessive amounts of alcohol in a short period of time.
topic: The effects of drinking on society

chunk_text: cannabis/marijuana is a drug made from the cannabis plant.
ganja/weed is a drug made from the cannabis plant.
hallucinogens are psychotoxic drugs that affect the mind in a way that produces distorted sensations.
sensory organ is an organ that receives and relays information about the body’s senses to the brain.
sclera is the tough, opaque tissue that serves as the eye’s protective outer layer.
cornea is a transparent structure over the front of the eye that allows light to enter. A cornea resembles a contact lens in size and appearance.
choroid is the middle layer filled with blood vessels that nourish the retina.
pupil is a hole in the centre of the iris that changes size in response to changes in lighting.
iris is a membrane in the eye, responsible for controlling the amount of light reaching the retina.
dilated means becomes wider.
constricted means becomes smaller.
lens is a flexible disc that helps focus light on the retina.
suspensory ligaments are elastic-like structures that suspend the lens and pull it into shape for focusing distant objects onto the retina.
ciliary muscles are eye muscles that automatically contract or relax the shape of the lens of the eye to help focus light on the retina.
retina is a light-sensitive tissue lining the inner surface of the eye.
rods are cells in the retina that perceive light and movement and work well in dim light.
cones are cells in the retina that perceive light and movement and only work in bright light.
diverging means spreading apart.
distant means far away.
convex means curving or bulging outwards.
converging means two or more things coming together.
concave means curving or bulging inwards.
astigmatism is an optical defect in which vision is blurred due to the inability of the optics of the eye to focus a point object into a sharp focused image on the retina.
outer ear is the part of the ear visible externally.
topic: The ear as a sense organ

chunk_text: middle ear is the main cavity of the ear, between the eardrum and the inner ear.
topic: The ear as a sense organ

chunk_text: inner ear is a complex system of interconnecting cavities, concerned with hearing and equilibrium.
topic: The ear as a sense organ

chunk_text: eardrum is the membrane in the ear that vibrates to sound.
topic: The ear as a sense organ

chunk_text: malleus (hammer) is the ossicle attached to the eardrum.
topic: The senses of balance and movement

chunk_text: incus (anvil) is the ossicle between the malleus and the stapes.
topic: The senses of balance and movement

chunk_text: stapes (stirrup) is the stirrup-shaped ossicle that transmits sound from the incus to the cochlea.
topic: The senses of balance and movement

chunk_text: ampullae is the swelling at the base of each semicircular canal, containing sensory cells which detect movement of the fluid within the canals.
topic: The senses of balance and movement

chunk_text: hormones are chemicals produced in one part of an organism which produce specific effects on a different part of the organism.
thyroxine is hormone produced by the thyroid glands to regulate metabolism by controlling the rate of oxidation in cells.
pancreas is a gland that produces digestive enzymes and manufactures hormones, including insulin and glucagon.
topic: Insulin, controlling the blood sugar levels and diabetes mellitus

chunk_text: insulin is a hormone that lowers the blood glucose level.
topic: Insulin, controlling the blood sugar levels and diabetes mellitus

chunk_text: glucagon is a hormone that raises the blood glucose level.
topic: Insulin, controlling the blood sugar levels and diabetes mellitus

chunk_text: glycogen is a form of carbohydrate stored primarily in the liver and broken down into glucose when needed by the body.
topic: Insulin, controlling the blood sugar levels and diabetes mellitus

chunk_text: adrenaline is a hormone produced by the adrenal glands that elevates heart and respiration rates; also called ‘epinephrine’.
testosterone is the primary male hormone responsible for the development of masculine traits.
secondary sexual characteristics distinguish between the two sexes; includes facial hair of the human male and enlarged hips and breasts of the female.
corpus luteum is the cell mass that remains after the release of an egg. It secretes both progesterone and oestrogen.
progesterone is a hormone that prepares the uterus for the implantation of a fertilised ovum and to maintain pregnancy.
implant means fix or set securely.
FSH (follicle stimulating hormone) is a hormone produced by the pituitary gland that stimulates the growth of eggs in the ovaries.
topic: The hormones of the menstrual cycle

chunk_text: LH (luteinising hormone) is a hormone that triggers the onset of ovulation. Works in concert with FSH.
topic: The hormones of the menstrual cycle

chunk_text: oestrogen is the primary female hormone responsible for the development of feminine traits.
topic: The hormones of the menstrual cycle

chunk_text: sexual intercourse is the erect penis of the male entering the vagina of the female.
ejaculation is the release of semen from the penis.
fertilisation is a single sperm combining with an ovum.
conception is a single sperm combining with an ovum.
zygote is a fertilised ovum.
contraceptive is the prevention of conception.
homeostasis is the body’s ability to maintain normal function and stability.
homoios means like, or the same.
stasis means state.
poikilotherms are animals whose internal temperature varies along with that of the ambient environmental temperature.
homoiotherms are animals whose internal temperature is relatively constant and independent of the environmental temperature.
dilate means to become wider or larger; expand.
topic: Physiological methods of temperature regulation in homoiotherms

chunk_text: constrict means squeeze, or press together.
topic: Physiological methods of temperature regulation in homoiotherms

chunk_text: vasoconstriction is the constriction of a blood vessel.
topic: Physiological methods of temperature regulation in homoiotherms

chunk_text: thermoregulatory centre is the area of the brain responsible for controlling body temperature.
excretion is the bodily process of discharging waste matter.
excretory organs are organs involved in excretion.
nitrogenous waste is a nitrogen-rich chemical waste of several cellular processes, excreted via urine.
osmoregulation is the control of the water and electrolyte balance in the body.
Bowman’s capsule is the expanded end of a kidney tubule or nephron that acts as a filter to produce urine.
topic: The roles of the different areas of a single kidney tubule in the production of urine are described below:

chunk_text: ultrafiltration is the removal of excess water and other substances from the blood.
topic: The roles of the different areas of a single kidney tubule in the production of urine are described below:

chunk_text: glomerular filtrate is the liquid resulting from filtration in the Bowman’s capsule.
topic: The roles of the different areas of a single kidney tubule in the production of urine are described below:

chunk_text: antidiuretic hormone (ADH) is a hormone produced by the pituitary gland that reduces the production of urine in the kidneys and thereby prevents water loss.
topic: The roles of the different areas of a single kidney tubule in the production of urine are described below:

chunk_text: sphincter is a ring of muscle that contracts to close an opening.
topic: The roles of the different areas of a single kidney tubule in the production of urine are described below:

chunk_text: urethra is a duct through which urine is discharged.
topic: The roles of the different areas of a single kidney tubule in the production of urine are described below:

chunk_text: osmoreceptors are specialised nerve cells responsible for monitoring the osmotic pressure of the blood and extracellular fluid.
topic: The roles of the different areas of a single kidney tubule in the production of urine are described below:

chunk_text: deamination is the removal of an amine group from a molecule.
waxy cuticle is a waterproof upper surface layer found in many types of leaf.
palisade mesophyll is the main photosynthetic tissue of a leaf.
spongy mesophyll is the main gas exchange tissue of a leaf.
lower epidermis is a surface layer of a leaf containing stomata.
stomata are pores mostly on the lower surface of leaves that can be opened or closed to control gas exchange and water loss.
guard cells are pairs of cells which surround and control the size of stomata by altering their shape.
vascular bundles are part of the transport system in vascular plants, containing xylem and phloem.
xylem are the hollow cells of a plant that transport water and minerals to plant cells.
phloem is the food-conducting living tissue of a plant.
chloroplast is the organelle in the cytoplasm of plant cells where chlorophyll is stored, and photosynthesis takes place.
photosynthesis is a plant chemical process of making food (sugars) and oxygen, from carbon dioxide and water, in the presence of light.
heterotrophs are organisms that obtain their energy through consuming other organisms.
autotrophs are organisms that make their own food from inorganic substances, via photosynthesis.
destarching is the process of eliminating starch reserves from a plant by depriving it of light.
radioactive tracers are radioactive molecules that can be sent through a vascular system (animal or plant) with their progress followed by a radiation-sensitive machine.
resurrection plants are plants with the habit of reviving after seeming to be dead.
transpiration is the process by which water absorbed by plants, usually through the roots, is evaporated into the atmosphere from the plant surface, principally from the leaves.
topic: The need for transport in plants

chunk_text: passive means requires no energy from the plant.
topic: The need for transport in plants

chunk_text: adhesive forces are forces of attraction between different types of molecule.
cohesive forces are forces of attraction between similar types of molecule.
cuticle is a waterproof upper surface layer found in many types of leaf.
hormones are chemicals produced in one part of an organism which produce specific effects on a different part of the organism.
endosperm is the nutritive tissue of a seed, consisting of carbohydrates, proteins and lipids.
plumule is the bud, or growing point, of the embryo, above the cotyledons.
radicle is the first part of a seedling (a growing plant embryo) to emerge from the seed during the process of germination.
cotyledons are the first leaves sent out by the germinating seed – the seed leaves.
testa is the hard external coating of a seed.
hypocotyl is the first leaf-like structure that appears on a germinating seed. It grows upward in response to light.
epigeal germination is when cotyledons are carried above the ground.
hypogeal germination is when cotyledons remain below the ground.
auxins are plant growth hormones.
gibberellic acid is a growth-stimulating and dormancy-breaking plant hormone.
cytokinin is plant hormones that promote cell division.
ethylene is a gaseous plant hormone that stimulates fruit ripening and the dropping of leaves.
abscisic acid (ABA) is a growth-inhibiting hormone.
apical dominance is growth concentrated in the terminal bud, allowing it to grow taller, thereby increasing its exposure to sunlight.
tropisms are the reactions of plants to stimuli.
gibberellins are a group of hormones that regulate plant growth.
phototropism is the tendency of plants to move or grow towards light.
hydrotropism is the tendency of plants to move or grow towards water.
indole-3-acetic acid (IAA) is a plant growth hormone.
topic: How are tropic responses brought about?

chunk_text: natural resources are resources (actual and potential) supplied by nature.
renewable means capable of being produced indefinitely, not used up.
non-renewable means once used, cannot be easily made or replaced.
extinct means no longer in existence.
conservation is the act of preserving, guarding or protecting.
monocultures are the cultivation of single crops.
endemic means unique to a particular geographic location.
sustainable resource means capable of being maintained and/or replaced.
pollution is the contamination of the natural environment by harmful substances as a result of human activities.
pollutant is a harmful substance.
hydrocarbons are substances containing only hydrogen and carbon. Fossil fuels are made of hydrocarbons.
particles are very small pieces of solid or liquid matter.
global dimming is a worldwide reduction of the sunlight reaching the Earth’s surface, caused by particulate air pollution.
carbon dioxide is a gas produced by living organisms as a waste product of respiration, and as a result of burning wood and fossil fuels.
carbon cycle is the global cycle of movement of carbon, in all of its forms, involving all living things and all parts of the environment.
carbon monoxide is a pollutant gas produced as a result of burning fossil fuels.
sulphur dioxide is a pollutant gas produced as a result of burning fossil fuels.
nitrogen oxides are pollutant gases produced as a result of burning fossil fuels.
acid rain is rain with a low pH containing sulphuric acid and nitric acid as a result of dissolving airborne pollutant gases.
